required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Human Epididymis Protein 4 in Normal Menstruating Women
clinical_study.official_title: Human Epididymis Protein 4 in Normal Menstruating Women

lead_sponsor.agency: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island

clinical_study.source: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if Human Epididymis Protein 4 (HE-4) levels vary during the menstrual cycles in ovulatory women. HE-4 is a sensitive serological marker that is elevated in certain ovarian and endometrial cancers and can aid in the diagnosis of these malignant conditions. In order to optimize the utility of HE4 as a tumor marker in premenopausal women, its expression in the normal menstrual cycle needs to be characterized. We hypothesize that HE-4 levels do not vary in the menstrual cycle.

intervention.description: 5 blood draws during ovulatory menstrual cycles in premenopausal women

study_pop.textblock: Ovulating women recruited from local college campuses, doctor's offices and hospitals.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- women age 18-45 years old
- regular menstrual cycles (every 25-35 days)
- normal BMI (19-25)
- no hormonal contraception in the two menstrual cycles prior to enrollment
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnancy
- pelvic mass

overall_official.affiliation: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island

facility.name: Women & Infants Hospital of Rhode Island, Division of Reproductive Endocrinology & Infertility

reference.citation: Anastasi E, Granato T, Marchei GG, Viggiani V, Colaprisca B, Comploj S, Reale MG, Frati L, Midulla C. Ovarian tumor marker HE4 is differently expressed during the phases of the menstrual cycle in healthy young women. Tumour Biol. 2010 Oct;31(5):411-5. doi: 10.1007/s13277-010-0049-1. Epub 2010 May 20.

A novel multiple marker bioassay utilizing HE4 and CA125 for the prediction of ovarian cancer in patients with a pelvic mass. Gynecol Oncol. 2009 Jan;112(1):40-6. doi: 10.1016/j.ygyno.2008.08.031. Epub 2008 Oct 12.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island
